. Hemispheric and large-scale land-surface air temperature variations: An extensive revision and an update to 2010.
48. Foster, G. & Rahmstorf, S. Global temperature evolution 1979–2010.
49. Kosaka, Y. & Xie, S.-P. The tropical Pacific as a key pacemaker of the variable rates of global warming.
50. Klimont, Z., Smith, S. & Cofala, J. The last decade of global anthropogenic sulfur dioxide: 2000–2011 emissions.
. Robust comparison of climate models with observations using blended land air and ocean sea surface temperatures.
52. Simmons, A. & Poli, P. Arctic warming in ERA-Interim and other analyses.
Quarterly Journal of the Royal Meteorological Society
53. Hansen, J., Ruedy, R., Sato, M. & Lo, K. Global surface temperature change.
. NOAA’s merged land-ocean surface temperature analysis.
Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society
. A New Estimate of the Average Earth Surface Land Temperature Spanning 1753 to 2011.
. Possible artifacts of data biases in the recent global surface warming hiatus.
. Extended Reconstructed Sea Surface Temperature version 5 (ERSSTv5): Upgrades, Validations, and
58. Shindell, D. Inhomogeneous forcing and transient climate sensitivity.
59. Lewandowsky, S., Risbey, J. & Oreskes, N. On the definition and identifiability of the alleged ‘hiatus’ in global warming.
The authors thank the UK MetOffice (HadCRUT4), Kevin Cowtan and Robert Way (HadCRUT4-CW), NASA/
GISS (GISS), NOAA (MLOST) and Berkeley Earth for providing the observed temperature datasets.
M.R.A. developed the methodology and designed the study. M.R.A. and K.H. wrote the code. K.H. performed the
uncertainty analysis and wrote the paper. P.M.F. provided the forcing data. P.M.F., F.E.L.O., D.M.M., H.D.M. and
D.J.F. provided extensive comments and helped in the initial design of the study.
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
